questions.questionText: Drag reactants to complete the following Williamson Ether Synthesis:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! You've successfully completed the Williamson Ether Synthesis. Sodium methoxide (a strong nucleophile) attacks bromoethane (an alkyl halide) in an SN2 reaction to form methyl ethyl ether.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. For Williamson Ether Synthesis, you need a strong nucleophile (an alkoxide) and an alkyl halide. Try again!
questions.chemistryNotes:
The Williamson Ether Synthesis is an important method for preparing ethers:

  • It involves an SN2 reaction between an alkoxide ion (RO-) and an alkyl halide (R'-X)
  • The alkoxide acts as a nucleophile and attacks the electrophilic carbon of the alkyl halide
  • The halide is displaced as a leaving group
  • The general reaction is: R-O- + R'-X → R-O-R' + X-

This reaction works best when the alkyl halide is primary or methyl, as these are most susceptible to SN2 reactions with minimal competing elimination.

questions.questionText: Select the reagents needed for this SN1 reaction to form tert-butyl ethyl ether under acidic conditions:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This SN1 reaction uses tert-butyl chloride (which forms a stable carbocation) reacting with ethanol to form tert-butyl ethyl ether.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. This is an SN1 reaction. Think about which reagent would readily form a carbocation and which would act as the nucleophile.
questions.chemistryNotes:
The SN1 (Substitution Nucleophilic Unimolecular) reaction occurs in two steps:

  1. The leaving group departs, forming a carbocation intermediate
  2. The nucleophile attacks the carbocation

Key characteristics:

  • Rate depends only on the concentration of the substrate (unimolecular)
  • Common with tertiary or secondary substrates that form stable carbocations
  • Follows first-order kinetics
  • Often occurs in polar protic solvents that can stabilize the carbocation

In this case, tert-butyl chloride readily forms a stable tertiary carbocation, which is then attacked by ethanol acting as a nucleophile.

questions.questionText: Select reagents to complete this E2 elimination reaction:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The strong base potassium tert-butoxide abstracts a hydrogen (deprotonation) from 2-bromo-2-methylpropane, causing elimination of HBr and forming the alkene 2-methylprop-1-ene.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. For an E2 elimination reaction, you need a strong base and an alkyl halide. The base abstracts a hydrogen while the halide leaves simultaneously.
questions.chemistryNotes:
E2 (Elimination Bimolecular) reactions occur in a single step:

  • A strong base abstracts a proton while the leaving group departs simultaneously
  • This creates a new π bond (C=C)
  • Rate depends on both substrate and base concentration (bimolecular)
  • Often favored with bulky bases like tert-butoxide
  • Follows anti-periplanar geometry (H and leaving group must be anti to each other)

The reaction is concerted, meaning bond breaking and bond formation happen simultaneously. E2 reactions generally require:

  1. A suitable leaving group (like a halide)
  2. A strong base
  3. A β-hydrogen that can be abstracted

questions.questionText: Complete this acid-catalyzed esterification reaction by selecting the correct reagents:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! This is a Fischer esterification reaction where acetic acid reacts with ethanol to form ethyl acetate (an ester) and water. The reaction is typically catalyzed by an acid like H2SO4.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Esterification requires a carboxylic acid and an alcohol. Try again with the correct combination.
questions.chemistryNotes:
Fischer Esterification is the acid-catalyzed reaction of a carboxylic acid with an alcohol to form an ester:

  • General reaction: RCOOH + R'OH ⇌ RCOOR' + H2O
  • The reaction is reversible and reaches equilibrium
  • Typically catalyzed by a strong acid (H2SO4, HCl, p-toluenesulfonic acid)
  • Can be driven forward by:
    • Using excess of one reagent
    • Removing water as it forms

Mechanism steps:

  1. Protonation of the carboxylic acid carbonyl
  2. Nucleophilic attack by the alcohol
  3. Proton transfer
  4. Loss of water to form the ester
  5. Deprotonation to form the final product

questions.questionText: Select reagents for this Grignard reaction to form 2-phenylethanol:
questions.correctFeedback: Correct! The Grignard reagent (phenylmagnesium bromide) acts as a nucleophile and attacks ethylene oxide. After acidic workup, this forms 2-phenylethanol.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Incorrect. Grignard reactions involve a Grignard reagent (R-MgX) acting as a nucleophile. Consider which reagent would serve this role.
questions.chemistryNotes:
Grignard Reactions use organomagnesium compounds (Grignard reagents) as strong nucleophiles:

  • Grignard reagents have the formula R-MgX (where X is a halide, typically Br or Cl)
  • They behave as sources of nucleophilic R- groups (carbanions)
  • They react with various electrophiles including:
    • Aldehydes and ketones to form alcohols
    • Epoxides to form alcohols with chain extension
    • CO2 to form carboxylic acids
  • Must be performed under anhydrous conditions (Grignard reagents are destroyed by water)
  • Typically carried out in ether solvents like diethyl ether or THF

In this case, the phenylmagnesium bromide opens the ethylene oxide ring, creating a new C-C bond and forming 2-phenylethanol after workup.
